keywords: Benthic macroinvertebrates, Community assessments, Biological integrity, Ecological quality, Wadeable streams, Physical and chemical environmental variables
abstract:
This text describes a method for collecting benthic macroinvertebrate samples from waded streams to assess biological integrity and ecological quality. Benthic macroinvertebrates are important indicators of water health, and the data collected will help identify taxonomic loss, which can be an indicator of pollution or other environmental issues.

The necessity of this method lies in the importance of monitoring the health of our streams and waterways. By collecting and identifying these organisms, we can gain insights into the overall health of the ecosystem and detect any changes or trends over time. This information is crucial for understanding the impact of human activities on aquatic environments and implementing measures to improve watershed health and salmon recovery.

The method requires measurement of physical and chemical environmental variables described in other methods within the Environmental Assessment Program of the Washington State Department of Ecology. These measurements provide important context for interpreting the benthic macroinvertebrate data, allowing for a more comprehensive assessment of stream health. By following this standardized protocol, we can ensure consistency and accuracy in our data collection efforts and make meaningful comparisons across different streams and regions.
description:
This method outlines the process for gathering benthic macroinvertebrate samples to conduct community-level assessments. The data derived from this analysis contributes to evaluations of biological integrity and ecological quality, or taxonomic diversity. The application of this procedure is confined to waded streams. It's essential to measure the accompanying physical and chemical environmental variables, as detailed in other protocols under the Washington State Department of Ecology's Environmental Assessment Program, Status and Trends Monitoring for Watershed Health & Salmon Recovery - Field Data Collection Protocol for Wadeable Streams.

To execute this method effectively, follow these technical steps:
1. Procure necessary equipment, which includes a kick net (preferably 0.3 mÂ²), a container to store samples, and a recording sheet or digital device for data collection.
2. Locate a suitable waded stream site. Ensure it meets the requirements of the specified protocol.
3. Prior to sampling, record the physical environmental variables as outlined in related methods. This includes parameters such as stream width, depth, flow velocity, and substrate type. Also, document the presence or absence of visible pollutants.
4. Collect benthic macroinvertebrates by wading into the stream with your feet planted firmly on the streambed. Use your kick net to gently sweep the bottom of the stream. Be mindful not to disturb the substrate excessively, as this may alter the sample composition.
5. After securing a sample, carefully transfer it into your container without causing significant disturbance or loss of organisms. Properly label and record details of the sampling location, date, and time for future reference.
6. Process the sample by identifying and recording each distinct taxon present. This may involve employing various techniques such as sorting and dissection to accurately distinguish between species.
7. Document environmental conditions during each sampling occasion. These may include water temperature, pH, dissolved oxygen levels, and turbidity.
8. Analyze the data collected to assess biological integrity and ecological quality based on taxonomic richness, diversity indices, and other relevant indicators.
9. Compare the results with established benchmarks or standards to evaluate the stream's health status relative to previous measurements and ecological expectations.
10. Document and report findings in a clear and concise manner for further analysis and potential use in watershed management initiatives.
